I'd like to share some insights on using AI to translate articles. Here is the core philosophy:

The best translation is actually rewriting.
Achieving high-quality results requires breaking the process down into steps.

However, this depends on the scenario. For general https://t.co/e2vKoSXLKE

result.text:
I'd like to share some insights on using AI to translate articles. Here is the core philosophy:

The best translation is actually rewriting.
Achieving high-quality results requires breaking the process down into steps.

However, this depends on the scenario. For general translation needs, a single rewrite is usually sufficient. Given the capabilities of current Large Language Models‚Äîespecially models like Gemini 3 Pro‚Äîthe quality of a one-shot rewrite is already quite impressive.

If you are aiming for professional-grade translation, it is necessary to have the AI proofread and polish the text after that initial rewrite.

Crucially, do not attempt to cram translation, proofreading, and polishing into a single prompt, unless the content is extremely short.

The main reason is something I mentioned yesterday: while models can handle very long inputs, they tend to cut corners and suffer from severe hallucinations if the required output is too long.

Imagine translating a 2,000-word article. If you ask the model to rewrite, then proofread, and finally polish it all at once, the output could easily balloon to 5,000 - 6,000 words. By the time it gets to the end, the quality will degrade significantly.

Therefore, translation, proofreading, and polishing are best performed independently.

Let's start with translation. The prompt doesn't need to be overly complex. Simply asking it to "rewrite" works well, provided you specify the following:
- The style of the article
- A glossary of common terms or mappings
- The target audience (optional)

For proofreading, you need to provide both the original text and the translation. The goal here is to check for omissions and errors. If your requirement for precision isn't extremely high, you can skip this step.

For polishing, you do not need the original English text anymore; the translation alone is sufficient. At this stage, you just need the model to check if the results flow smoothly and if the phrasing adheres to native expression habits. The original text is no longer necessary.

Additionally, if the article is too long, you should split it into blocks. It is best to split by natural chapters or paragraphs; usually, splitting at the paragraph level is enough.

As for how to ensure continuity between the current block and the previous one, a simple and effective method is to add the source text and translation of the previous block into the context. This allows the translation of the next block to reference the content and style of the one before it.

Regarding how much history to retain, that depends on the model and the size of the blocks. Usually, the source and translation of the immediately preceding block are enough; you don't need too much history. In fact, sometimes providing no history at all works fine.

This process can be automated via a program using an API, or done manually within the model interface. Personally, I use Gemini. I create different "Gems" for different prompts, and when I need them, I simply paste the content into the corresponding Gem.

result.text:
WHITE FERTILITY COLLAPSED - THE REST OF THE PLANET DIDN‚ÄôT  

The generation now starting school is the first in recorded history that will grow up on a planet where people of European descent are a shrinking global minority.

Native fertility across the entire Western world has collapsed below replacement and shows no sign of recovery. Italy sits at 1.24 children per woman, Spain 1.23, Germany 1.36, Poland 1.26, Canada 1.33, Australia 1.58. Even the U.S. non-Hispanic white rate is only 1.64. Meanwhile Turkey is 1.99, Egypt 2.9, Nigeria 5.2, Pakistan 3.4, Indonesia 2.2, and most of sub-Saharan Africa remains above 4.

Layer on top the largest sustained migration in human history. Between 2000 and 2025 roughly 110 million people moved from the global South to Europe, North America, and Australia, with UN projections showing another 200-300M by mid-century. No previous empire, no previous century, has ever seen population movement on this scale.

The result is already visible in every major Western city. Native children are minorities today in the public schools of London, Paris, Amsterdam, Stockholm, Toronto, Sydney, and most large American metros. The rest of the West is simply next in line. By 2040-2050 the native-born of European descent will be minorities in the under-30 age group in every single Western country without exception.

This is no longer a national story. It is the biggest demographic turnover the world has ever witnessed, happening in one human lifetime, driven by fertility differentials no government has ever reversed and migration flows no democracy has ever stopped once they reach critical mass.

The same elites who spent 30 years dismissing these trends as racist fever dreams now quietly place their own children in private schools that remain 80-90% white or East Asian while lecturing the rest of us to celebrate the transformation they personally avoid.

History has watched founding populations lose demographic dominance before. It has never once ended with the old culture, language, or social trust intact. The West is running the experiment at global scale and warp speed.

The numbers don‚Äôt negotiate. They simply arrive, one kindergarten class at a time, until the old world is gone.

The other day I shared, "We were made an example to the world for a reason. We lead the way from darkness to LIGHT, Sovereignty. Humanity wants what we were given, A Constitution that protects us. Many would unite or join with us if they thought it was possible. Unity is strength. N & S". 

I am being shown imagery of maps and how they change over time. Not just the landscapes, but the societies, the people. Much of these changes occurred through violent conquer. Over coming the native populations through the culling's of the males and the impregnation of the females to create a new population. This culling happened on every continent and in every culture. Even in the America's with the indigenous tribes of both continents.

Each culture has its differences and its similarities. The United States may have initially started similarly to other Nations and cultures through conquering. It did not stay that way. 

After the initial creation of this country and its 13 colonies, now states, each new territory got to CHOOSE for themselves if they wanted to join this union. Each new state voted amongst their people to join this union VOLUNTARILY. None of them were conquered. Each joined by CHOICE.

If given the choice how many other nations or their people would choose to become a state in this union? Each following our Constitution by CHOICE. What makes this Country different from the rest of the world? We are given a choice and are allowed to change our minds choosing differently. We are allowed to tear down our government when it no longer represents us and build a new one built on the same Constitution adding guardrails to keep history from repeating again.

These aspects are what has set the United States apart and has had the world over trying to infiltrate and destroy it from within. Each of those societies were built upon layers of darkness through violence and conquering. Each were built upon pain, suffering and FEAR of those governing them. In the beginning the USA was no different until it abolished slavery. It was then it began to change.

What is different in the United States so sets it apart is every adult who comes here does so of their own free will choice. result.text:
Part I: The Wall & The Concrete

The light was dying over the terraced rows of Sheffield, surrendering to a bruised purple bruise of a sky. It was a Tuesday in November, the kind of evening that crept into your bones and stayed there.

In the narrow alleyway behind number 42, the rhythm was constant. A heartbeat of violence and control.

Thwack. Scuff. Thwack. Scuff.

Leo wiped his nose on the sleeve of his oversized polyester hoodie. He was eight years old, small for his age, with knobbly knees that turned pink in the cold. The air smelled of damp brick, wet leaves, and the faint, taunting aroma of frying chips drifting from Mrs. Higgins‚Äô kitchen window two doors down.

Inside number 42, the warm glow of the television flickered against the living room curtains. His mates were online right now, headsets on, warm and comfortable.

Leo didn‚Äôt care. He was at war with the wall.

It was a Victorian red-brick wall, uneven and unforgiving. The mortar had crumbled away in patches, creating unpredictable angles that would send the ball careening off toward the drainpipe if you didn't hit the center of the brick dead-on.

"First touch," Leo whispered to the steam of his own breath.

He backed up three paces. The ball was a heavy, waterlogged Mitre that had lost its white sheen months ago; now it was the color of the pavement.

He drove his laces through it. Bang.

The ball hit the wall with a wet slap. It rebounded aggressively, skidding low over the slick cobblestones. A bad touch would send it bouncing off his shin; a lazy touch would kill it dead. Leo needed the perfect touch‚Äîthe one that absorbed the energy but kept the ball rolling just enough to strike again.

He trapped it with the inside of his left foot. Not his good foot. The ball adhered to his sneaker for a fraction of a second, then rolled six inches forward. Perfect.

Bang.

The wall threw it back, faster this time.

Bang.

"And it‚Äôs Leo..." he muttered, the imaginary commentary running a frantic loop in his head. "...takes it past the defender..."

He hit a jagged piece of brick. The ball spun wildly to the right, heading straight for the waist-high patch of stinging nettles bordering Mrs. Higgins‚Äô fence. The "Graveyard," the local boys called it. If the ball went in there, you paid for it in welts and itching powder misery.

Leo didn't panic. He reacted. It wasn't a conscious thought; it was a spark in the nervous system. He lunged, stretching his leg, hooking his foot around the leather sphere just as it kissed the first nettle leaf. He dragged it back, spun his body, and in one fluid motion, hammered it back against the wall.

Thump.

His thigh stung from the cold. His toes were numb inside his cheap cleats. But in his chest, there was a heat that had nothing to do with temperature. It was a tightness, a desperate need to make the next touch better than the last one. It was the fear of being average.

The back door creaked open. A slice of yellow light cut across the dark wet stones.

"Leo!" his mum‚Äôs voice called out, weary but kind. "Tea‚Äôs on. Get in before you catch your death."

Leo trapped the ball one last time, freezing it dead under his sole. He looked at the wall. There was a faint, dark circle on the brick where he had hit it a thousand times, a bruise on the architecture.

"One more," Leo shouted back.

"Leo..."

"Just one more, Mum. I promise."

He waited until the door clicked shut. Then he stayed for another hour.

üçå nano banana pro prompt (with gemini)

Dynamically generate a current weather card based on a given city name.

--- prompt ---

Present a clear, 45¬∞ top-down view of a vertical (9:16) isometric miniature 3D cartoon scene, highlighting iconic landmarks centered in the composition to showcase precise and delicate modeling.

The scene features soft, refined textures with realistic PBR materials and gentle, lifelike lighting and shadow effects. Weather elements are creatively integrated into the urban architecture, establishing a dynamic interaction between the city's landscape and atmospheric conditions, creating an immersive weather ambiance.

Use a clean, unified composition with minimalistic aesthetics and a soft, solid-colored background that highlights the main content. The overall visual style is fresh and soothing.

Display a prominent weather icon at the top-center, with the date (x-small text) and temperature range (medium text) beneath it. The city name (large text) is positioned directly above the weather icon. The weather information has no background and can subtly overlap with the buildings.

The text should match the input city's native language.
Please retrieve current weather conditions for the specified city before rendering.
